title: With Trump's call for China to investigate Bidens, he's not even hiding: Today's talker
text:
CLOSE Impeaching a U.S. president might not be the be-all-end-all for their career. We explain why this is the case. Just the FAQs, USA TODAY

Donald Trump's behavior with China and Joe Biden shows how much he depends on Americans being desensitized to his repeated ethics violations

Already under the threat of an impeachment inquiry, President Donald Trump said Thursday morning that China should investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter Biden. In 2013, shortly after traveling to China on an official visit with his father, Hunter was issued a Chinese business license for his new private equity fund.

Don't let Trump shape a new normal

By Lisa Gilbert

The Ukraine scandal that unfolded with lightning speed has been stunning, and the ongoing revelations of corruption are even more so. Like a mafia don, President Donald Trump — having withheld nearly $400 million in aid to Ukraine — put the squeeze on Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky to dig up dirt on a political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden, and his son, Hunter Biden. The pressure campaign spanned months and implicates Vice President Mike Pence's office, Attorney General William Barr and the president’s personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani.

But he didn’t stop there. Just Thursday, Trump casually referenced to reporters the need for yet another foreign power to look into the Bidens, China. In addition, on Monday, news broke that Trump pushed the Australian prime minister during a recent telephone call to help Barr gather information for a Justice Department inquiry that Trump surely hopes will discredit former special counsel Robert Mueller’s findings. This was followed by the revelation that Barr also sought foreign assistance from British and Italian officials in investigating the Mueller report. And this is likely only just the beginning of the revelations to come.

Game over for the NCAA: California law takes paying college athletes out of the NCAA's hands: Today's talker

President Trump seems to think that if he keeps committing impeachable offenses, he can somehow normalize them and escape accountability. Yet in some ways, the barrage of news over the past week and a half has felt less shocking than it should have, because morally reprehensible, unethical and corrupt behavior is status quo for the Trump administration, and conflicts of interest, self-dealing and mobster tactics have become the new normal. When caught, Trump simply cranks up the spin machine, attacks his opponents and deflects attention by raising tariffs or rolling out another harsh immigration policy. And the country turns its attention to the next story.

It's Trump's normal, but not ours

Trump’s behavior in this latest scandal shows us how much he depends on the nation taking ethics violations for granted and how important it is that we shake off this desensitization as an impeachment inquiry to hold the president accountable becomes our new reality.

The danger, of course, is that we won’t.

Ukraine whistleblower (Photo: Adam Zyglis/The Buffalo (New York) News/PoliticalCartoons.com)

After all, the Ukraine scandal is right in line with Trump’s pattern of corrupt behavior, and he is relying on the tried-and-true spin tactics that have seen him through his 2 1/2 years in office despite unceasing scandalous ethics revelations.

Consider Trump’s properties, which he still owns even though his family is managing them. Any money spent at those properties goes into Trump’s pocket. Anyone who wants to try to influence Trump — including foreign leaders — can do so by staying at his hotels or frequenting his golf courses. When foreign leaders do it, it’s a violation of the Constitution’s anti-corruption (emoluments) clause. It happens routinely, mostly without our knowledge. It’s hardly news anymore.

Foreign leaders make sure Trump knows that they spend money at his businesses. In the July 25 phone call with Trump, Zelensky noted that on a previous trip to the United States, he stayed at the Trump International Hotel and Tower near Central Park in New York City.

Then consider Trump’s family. It’s ironic that Trump was pushing Zelensky to uncover the “corruption” surrounding Biden's son, given the unsavoriness surrounding the Trump brood.

For example, this Father’s Day, Ivanka Trump tweeted a photo with her father’s “Make America Great Again” slogan. In doing so, she likely violated the Hatch Act, which prohibits federal employees from using their official positions to influence an election. Still worse, she did this just days after the Office of Special Counsel found repeated violations of this law by counselor Kellyanne Conway and recommended that she be fired.

Then-Vice President Joe Biden, left, and his son Hunter Biden in Washington, D.C., in January 2010. (Photo: Alexis C. Glenn/Pool)

This type of behavior has been endemic in this administration, so it’s more than a little rich for Trump to anoint himself a crusader against corruption involving familial ties. While it’s possible that Hunter Biden was selected to do business in Ukraine because he was the vice president’s son (and Joe Biden could have asked him not to take the job), the claims of corruption allegedly committed by the Bidens in Ukraine have been debunked.

So when the whistleblower complaint and a call summary showed that the president had solicited a thing arguably of monetary value from the president of Ukraine in connection with U.S. elections — a violation of federal campaign finance laws — it might have felt like just another drop of water in the tidal wave of corruption that has washed over the country since Trump took office.

Indeed, the administration is trying to make the situation appear like a just a regular day at the office, with Trump spewing lies to undermine and spin.

However, as we all assess this clear story of extortion, we must remember that what Trump himself has admitted doing is a shocking abuse of power that threatens the foundational principles of our constitutional democracy.

And that is not normal.

Lisa Gilbert is the vice president of legislative affairs at Public Citizen. Follow her on Twitter @Lisa_PubCitizen

What others are saying

Sarah Chayes, The Atlantic: "Biden was one of the most vocal champions of anti-corruption efforts in the Obama administration. So when this same Biden takes his son with him to China aboard Air Force Two, and within days Hunter joins the board of an investment advisory firm with stakes in China ... Joe Biden has enabled this brand of practice, made it bipartisan orthodoxy. And the ethical standard in these cases — people’s basic understanding of right and wrong — becomes whatever federal law allows. Which is a lot."

David Axelrod, Twitter: "The (Trump) China play today heightened my hunch that he expects bad news out of the closed door (Former Special Representative for Ukraine Kurt) Volker hearing and wanted to change the subject. ... Another motivation, obviously, if you do publicly with China what you did surreptitiously with Ukraine, it, by his thinking, abets your argument that there’s nothing wrong with enlisting other countries to go after your political enemies on your behalf."

Tom Rogan, Washington Examiner: "President Trump's phone conversation with President Zelensky of Ukraine is deeply problematic. But Joe Biden's decision to allow his son Hunter to travel with him on a 2013 trip to China is a problem for the former vice president. ... When you're dealing with the Chinese, the lines between business and politics aren't just blurred, they are often symbiotic. ... As the child of a vice president, Hunter would have been under Secret Service protection in 2013. Tempered to protective security requirements, those records should now be released."

What our readers are saying

Trump is at it again. Trying to deflect anything against him onto someone else. He knows that Biden probably has the best chance to beat him, hence Trump trying to get something on him.

— Kay Jones

Yeah, China should investigate ... because Trump trusts China, Ukraine and Russia more than his FBI and CIA.

— Tom Kane

Trump is still better than anyone the Democrats have running.

— Jonathan Corbett

I don't doubt that a whole lot of Democrats would like to see Trump impeached; however, his support with his base is strong.

— Fleetwood Davant
